facts.text: Petitioner's husband Shri Balirambhau Doye, proprietor of certain forests in eight several Tehsils and Zamindar of Pandharpur, granted an unregistered document dated April 26, 1948, to petitioner giving her right to take and appropriate all kinds of wood - building wood, fuel wood, bamboos etc. - from the said forests for period from date of document up to December 26, 1960, for consideration of Rs. 26,000.
Genuineness of the document dated April 26, 1948, and good faith of parties not questioned.

Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950 enacted; came into force on January 26, 1951; under s.3 all proprietary rights vested in State on date fixed in notification - March 31, 1951 for this area.
After March 31, 1951, petitioner stopped from cutting trees.

Petitioner applied to Deputy Commissioner, Bhandara under s.6 of the Act; on August 16, 1955 held s.6 not apply as transfer before March 16, 1950 but Act not apply to pre-March 16, 1950 transfers; lease genuine; allowed petitioner to work forests subject to conditions in lease and rules under s.218A C. Land Revenue Act.
Petitioner claimed compensation from Government for 1951-1955 ouster but gave up on understanding allowed to work remaining term per Deputy Commissioner order.
Petitioner applied twice to Divisional Forest Officer, Bhandara for permission per order; received letter claim being examined.
Petitioner entered forests and started cutting trees (as per Divisional Forest Officer).
Divisional Forest Officer (respondent No.3) on March 19, 1956 directed petitioner to stop cutting forest wood, cancelled her name, forfeited cut materials.
Petitioner applied to Government of Madhya Pradesh on September 27, 1956 to direct Divisional Forest Officer to give possession and not interfere.

Petition to Supreme Court under Art.32 on August 26, 1957 praying set aside order of March 19, 1956 and writ to respondents not to interfere with rights to enter forests, appoint agents, obtain renewal passes, manufacture charcoal etc.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order dated March 19, 1956 infringes petitioner's fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g).

Nature of rights under the unregistered document dated April 26, 1948: proprietary interest, lease, license, license coupled with grant, profit a prendre, or contractual right; whether it affects immovable property requiring registration; whether rights survived vesting under MP Abolition Act s.3.
Whether the document conveys movable or immovable property; distinction between standing timber and trees.

petitioner_arguments.text: Offending order infringes fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g) derived from document dated April 26, 1948.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.19(1)(f), 19(1)(g); Chhotabhai Jethabhai Patel & Co. v. State of Madhya Pradesh

petitioner_arguments.text: Rights flow from contract; entitled to writ.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Chhotabhai Jethabhai Patel & Co. v. State of Madhya Pradesh

petitioner_arguments.text: Deputy Commissioner order August 16, 1955 validates rights.

respondent_arguments.text: Document does not confer proprietary rights or interest; rights extinguished on vesting under s.3 MP Abolition Act.
Petitioner unlawfully entered and cut trees.

court_reasoning.text: Whatever construction of document: if proprietary share, unregistered so no effect on immovable property; even if acquired, vested in State under s.3 MP Act, claim compensation only. If license, extinguished on vesting. If profit a prendre (interest in land/immovable), unregistered no effect. If personal contractual right, State not party, no acquisition, petitioner can sue grantor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No infringement of fundamental right under Art.19(1)(f) or (g); Art.32 petition not maintainable.

court_reasoning.text: Document is not lease conferring enjoyment of land but license coupled with grant to enter and take produce (profit a prendre); not transfer under s.105 TPA.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Follows Ananda Behera v. State of Orissa.

court_reasoning.text: Right to cut over 12 years includes trees benefiting from soil nourishment; not mere standing timber (movable) but trees (immovable); requires registration as value Rs.26,000.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Standing timber: trees fit for building etc., intended to be cut soon; here long term, multiple cuttings, prohibited small girth, no obligation to cut immediately.

court_reasoning.text: If contractual simpliciter, no fundamental right breached as State not party.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Differs from Chhotabhai on writ maintainability.

holdings.text: No fundamental right infringed; petition under Art.32 not maintainable.
Unregistered document dated April 26, 1948 does not confer enforceable interest in immovable property; rights if any do not survive vesting or bind State.
Grant over 12 years of right to fell trees as they mature is immovable property requiring registration.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ananda Behera v. The State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Profit a prendre is interest in immovable property; unregistered document ineffective; no fundamental right.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chhotabhai Jethabhai Patel & Co. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Writ held maintainable for license/contractual rights but differed on Art.32 maintainability; would have been decided differently if contract aspect highlighted.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition for enforcement of fundamental rights; no infringement found.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Proprietary rights vested in State; s.6 not applicable to pre-1950 transfer but rights extinguished.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Registration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Unregistered document does not affect immovable property.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Not a lease; standing timber excluded from immovable property.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Immovable property includes benefits arising out of land; trees attached to earth.

statutes_cited.name: Central Provinces Land Revenue Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Rules for working forests subject to Deputy Commissioner order.

outcome.summary: Petition under Art.32 dismissed as no fundamental right infringed; whatever rights under unregistered document do not bind State post-vesting under MP Abolition Act and do not constitute property under Art.19(1)(f)/(g).

key_quotes.text: whatever construction be put on this document, the petitioner cannot complain of the breach of any of her fundamental rights.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding by Das C.J. on no Art.19 violation.

key_quotes.text: the document only confers a right to enter on the lands in order to cut down certain kinds of trees and carry away the wood... a licence to enter on the land coupled with a grant to cut certain trees on it and carry away the wood.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Bose J. characterizes nature of right as profit a prendre.

key_quotes.text: Standing timber must be a tree that is in a state fit for these purposes and, further, a tree that is meant to be converted into timber so shortly that it can already be looked upon as timber for all practical purposes even though it is still standing.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines distinction between trees (immovable) and standing timber (movable).
